Good, I’m wired up, that’s good. So, the
weekend before last I was sitting in the park

504.text:
with two friends, one of them happened to
be a climate scientist, the other was a columnist

508.text:
on a newspaper and it was a lovely, lovely
day, do you remember, the weekend before last.

515.text:
And we’re sitting there and people in the
park doing all of the things that the pictures

521.text:
in the newspapers the next day showed them
doing there, kids where playing, bouncing

526.text:
balls, people licking ice cream and of course
we are completely miserable. We’re sitting

534.text:
there on this gorgeous day grumbling, not
surprisingly and actually also saying to ourselves

541.text:
what miserable gits we are, that we cannot
enjoy this lovely afternoon. The reason being

548.text:
of course that we’ve been affected by the
climate change bug. And we were seeing, the

554.text:
world that we were seeing that day was through
the lens of what we knew about climate change.

560.text:
We knew in our bones and of course it was
confirmed the next day that it was the hottest

563.text:
November day ever recorded, which was why
it was hard for us to join in the fun that

571.text:
was all about us. There is something kind
of unnerving about weather like this that

577.text:
feels familiar, but that you actually know
is somehow not genuine. Freud had a sense

583.text:
of how things that where not quite what they
seem to be, could be actually could be deeply

589.text:
disturbing. He called it ‘unheimlich’
– ‘unhomely’, though I would actually

594.text:
translate that as ‘uncanny’ and this was
an uncanny day. Climate change is now well

601.text:
underway and accelerating. October was the
367th consecutive month with global temperatures

611.text:
above the 20th century average. I say that
again 367 months in a row that climate has

620.text:
been above the average, in fact that average
hardly means anything now. You know on weather

624.text:
forecasts they ‘say unseasonal weather’
or they say ‘temperatures above normal’,

628.text:
we’re moving into this uncanny world, where
the normal is no longer normal, there is no

634.text:
normal, we’re beyond normal. And I could
talk a great deal of length about where this

637.text:
is taking us and when I did my first draft
of this talk, I waxed lyrical about the worst

644.text:
possible predictions of ‘business as usual’
climate impacts: Collapse of agricultural

651.text:
production in the main grain areas, the death
of oceans, the submersion of most world’s

656.text:
great cities, millions of people on the move,
the annihilation of sub-Saharan Africa, we

662.text:
can go on, there is plenty out there as you
know. And already I suspect, even as I start

667.text:
to mention these things as bullet points,
your attention may very well be drifting away,

672.text:
maybe I’ve been talking quite long enough
for it to drift away, but whenever we talk

677.text:
about these impacts, it is hard to maintain
focus. We would prefer not to care, no, it’s

687.text:
not that we don’t care, but we would prefer
not to have to care, I guess that’s the

693.text:
key-point. We want to make that choice between
what we pay attention to and what to ignore.

699.text:
And like many people who work on this issue
professionally, I keep myself sane by never

705.text:
looking too deeply at the issue I work on.
Those of us who work on this can already in

711.text:
ourselves see some of the models for why other
people do not accept it. I find that I take

717.text:
on just as much information as I require and
no more. And I guess climate change for many

722.text:
of us who work on this issue professionally,
is like a huge collective secret, where we

729.text:
all memorise one line, but we make sure we
don’t put it all together. And my friends

735.text:
who work professionally as scientists and
this is very interesting, say that actually

740.text:
for many of them there is a taboo about actually
talking about the issue as a whole in casual

747.text:
conversations, it’s that thing of putting
the whole story together, you work on one

749.text:
small part, rather than the whole. What’s
more I think, because we’re all deeply implicated

757.text:
in climate change, listening to the science
and accepting that problem means accepting

763.text:
the poisoned apple of knowledge that all of
our actions, however well intentioned, however

767.text:
pleasurable could be directly linked to that
wider crime. So is it surprising when people

773.text:
look at it that they go: “You know what,
I don’t think I really need to know about

776.text:
that”. You know is there any surprise that
people want to play ball? They want to eat

782.text:
ice cream rather than join us on our grumpy
bench. You know in that film ‘When Harry

787.text:
met Sally’ there is that great scene where
the lady at the table, she overhears Meg Ryan

793.text:
having her false orgasm as she is eating her
Reuben sandwich and she says: “I’ll have

798.text:
what she’s having.” And with any surprise
what people who overhear our conversations

802.text:
say: “You know what, I don’t think I’m
going to have what they are having, I’m

805.text:
going to keep well away from that.” And
that is an act of choice, that’s one of

808.text:
the reasons why people don’t accept this
and maybe it’s actually the fault of having

814.text:
a Reuben salad in Katz’s Deli, which incidentally
was on the other side of the street from the

819.text:
tenement building I used to live in New York
city that reminds me of the story of Jan Karski.

824.text:
Now Jan Karski was a Polish resistance fighter
and he’d witnessed the murder of Polish

831.text:
Jews in Belsen concentration camp, very unusual,
but he’d seen this, he managed to escape

835.text:
and he’d gone to America to try and persuade
people of the extended Nazi genocide that

840.text:
was under full steam at that point in 1942.
To his dismay few people believed him. He

847.text:
went and spoke to Felix Frankfurter. Felix
Frankfurter was the Supreme Court judge and

851.text:
one of the smartest, brightest legal minds
of his generation. And Felix Frankfurter could

858.text:
not accept what he was saying. But this was
eyewitness testimony, why could he not accept

863.text:
it? Frankfurter said: “I don’t say that
the young man is lying, I said I’m unable

871.text:
to believe him and that is different.” Despite
the vast differences between the Holocaust

880.text:
and climate change it does have this much
in common, that they are both almost beyond

886.text:
imagination and as I’ll explain, if anything
kills us, it’s not the lack of rationality,

894.text:
it could be a lack of imagination. And so
maybe like Justice Frankfurter, we find that

902.text:
we can hold that state of knowledge without
the state of believes, we can keep these two

908.text:
things separate. So last week there was a
US poll, these are very regular occurrences

913.text:
these polls, people in America they like their
polls. A poll came out in which two-thirds

919.text:
of people said that climate change is happening.
There is a very broad based support that there

924.text:
is something serious going on, but scarcely
10% of people expressed any great concern

930.text:
about it; now in Britain things may be not
quite so polarized. In Britain the vast bulk

936.text:
of people that’s 70% of people consistently
in the opinion polls are ‘somewhat concerned’.

944.text:
Which actually I think you can read as ‘well,
as you happen to mention it, while I think

949.text:
about it, well yes I suppose, I suppose that
is a bit concerning, yes, yes. So what was

955.text:
the question again’? Because one of the
strange things, I do a lot of focus group

961.text:
work and one of the strange things is, if
you don’t specifically ask people about

964.text:
climate change, strangely no one seems to
mention it. In dozens of focus groups and

971.text:
polls across Britain, on the lead-up to the
last election, no one mentioned climate change

978.text:
as a major issue that they wish to have addressed
by an incoming government. I read the polls,

984.text:
I read the surveys, climate change was not
on there and even when people where prompted,

989.text:
they were given a list of issues that they
wanted the future government to deal with,

992.text:
climate change never came off the bottom of
the heap. So is it any surprising that then

998.text:
when we went into the election campaign, with
the exception of Natalie Bennett who, I mean

1002.text:
she is Green Party, so she is going to mention
it, but with the exception of her, do not

1006.text:
appear in the debates, it does not even appear
as a question in the debates. It is therefore,

1011.text:
because of a public lack of engagement, it
is removed from a political discourse. We

1016.text:
know politicians have their own agendas, but
nonetheless the agenda is ultimately led by

1020.text:
what people mention and let’s face it the
last election was the most focus group led

1024.text:
election in my experience. Now, we have lots
of terms for mass concern, we can talk about

1035.text:
mania or panic or terror or hysteria, but
we don’t seem to have any term for mass

1040.text:
indifference in the face of an overwhelming
threat, I mean what do we call it? Rampant

1045.text:
mass wisteria? I don’t know. Cerebral diletantia?
Cronic distructivitis? I don’t know, please,

1052.text:
you know, suggest a name! And I think we live
under some massive conjuring trick, some huge

1059.text:
sleight of hand, we’re all so busy tapping
into our electronic toys, but we don’t notice

1063.text:
the trapdoor opening up underneath our feet.
The truth is humans are very good at ignoring

1071.text:
things; it’s a key part of our intelligence.
Recent cognitive psychologies become far more

1077.text:
interested in how it is that we come to ignore
things than how it is that we come to pay

1081.text:
attention to them, because we live in an information
saturated society and it is our capacity to

1086.text:
ignore things, which keeps us sane. So for
example I’m able to look and scan across

1093.text:
your faces now, without my cortex exploding
from the sheer amount of information contained

1102.text:
in looking at you all, which certainly would
make for a lively talk, but nonetheless I

1108.text:
can look across and I can see a friend, I
can see someone I know, I can recognise someone

1115.text:
and the reason that I can do that is because
I can disregard and detach all of the information

1120.text:
of every other face that I’m looking at.
I mean, nothing personal, but we do it all

1125.text:
the time, don’t we? So we have this capacity
to ignore things, we also seek to avoid anxiety

1133.text:
and stress; we do everything we can to ignore
the things, which might cause it. But of course

1140.text:
that’s not enough, because if what we did
was we just ignored things, which caused us

1144.text:
anxiety, then life would be blissful, but
short, because we depend, we depend on our

1151.text:
ability to pick out certain things. We depend
for our survival on safety mechanisms that

1157.text:
alert us to issues that we really do have
to pay attention to, that cut through those

1163.text:
natural biases and demand our attention. And
here is one of the problems with climate change,

1168.text:
because it is singularly poorly constructed
for engaging those innate mechanisms. We respond

1174.text:
most strongly to threats that are here, that
are now, that are visible, that have a clear

1180.text:
cause, that can be dealt with readily through
simple actions, things that threaten, violent

1185.text:
and personal impacts and especially things
that come from a familiar enemy, because as

1190.text:
social animals we are acutely geared to paying
attention to things from enemies. We might

1196.text:
add additional cultural components that demand
our attention, things that cause disgust for

1203.text:
example, things that break social convention,
things that threaten social disapproval; we

1209.text:
constantly have these signals, these antenna,
which are looking out for these social signals.

1213.text:
Eating puppies for example, for years I’ve
been trying to point out that one of the impacts

1220.text:
of climate change might be we’re forced
to eat puppies. It’s not a message, which

1223.text:
has gone down very well, but if we could argue
that, there’s no question we would demand

1228.text:
and attract people’s attention. Climate
change scores very poorly on every single

1237.text:
one of these points, which is why our newspapers
are full of stories of the things that do

1243.text:
score highly on those points, like Ebola,
which as far as I’m aware has not killed

1250.text:
a single person in Britain. Islamic State,
which executes people on YouTube, these things

1259.text:
are very visible, clear, intent, with enemies
driving them. Or indeed we’re talking about

1265.text:
social disapproval whether or not Jeremy Corbin
kneels or doesn’t kneel or how deeply he

1271.text:
bows on Remembrance Sunday and so on. So our
cognition is dictated by biases, ingrained

1279.text:
systems that direct our attention towards
these triggers, what we could call these salient

1284.text:
triggers, these things, which demand our attention.
Professor Daniel Kahneman won a Nobel Price

1292.text:
for his pioneering work in the identification
of cognitive biases. I don’t know if you’ve

1297.text:
read, I strongly recommend his book ‘Thinking
Fast, Thinking Slow’. Professor Kahneman

1303.text:
told me that in his view climate change contains
a toxic combination of these biases. Not only

1313.text:
is it uncertain, it is in the future and it
requires substantial costs, all areas that

1322.text:
his research tells him that we’re very poorly
set up to cope with or to pay attention to,

1328.text:
but it has the worst possible combination
of these three. It requires certain current

1335.text:
costs to avoid larger, but yet uncertain costs
at some time in the future. He’s a very

1343.text:
nice man and he just said: “I’m so sorry,”
I said: “There’s no skin of my nose Professor

1352.text:
Kahneman.” He said: ”I’m so sorry,”
he says “I can see no hope on this issue.”

1357.text:
So he is welcome on our bench, we can sit
there like other people licking their ice

1362.text:
cream together. But we have to remember that
that’s maybe what cognitive psychology experiments

1369.text:
tell us and we need to recall that the vast
majority of these experiments are conducted

1375.text:
and depend for their research data on undergraduates.
And it’s a group from which one can’t

1382.text:
necessarily infer universal truths. Considering
that I chain-smoked through my years here

1390.text:
at Bristol and that was when I wasn’t in
an alcohol induced coma, I don’t really

1396.text:
think that I would trust anything I might
have said at that time about future costs,

1400.text:
no actually I’m going to take the point
even further in terms of future costs, my

1405.text:
friends who would subsidise their drinking
by visits to the sperm donor clinic, which

1409.text:
surely would cause a complete nightmare to
any [inaudible]. So we’ll also know that

1415.text:
not only can’t we entirely trust what comes
through the limited context of an experiment,

1422.text:
but this is only one part of the story, we
know this from our own experience, don’t

1426.text:
we? I mean we invest billions in defence and
insurance and anticipation of uncertain future

1432.text:
threats. Humans have an extraordinary capacity
for altruism, for long-term thinking. We can

1438.text:
tolerate any cost including the risk to our
own lives if necessary, if this is in the

1446.text:
context of something, which is sufficiently
endorsed and condoned and rewarded by wider

1452.text:
society. I repeat that, if it is sufficiently
endorsed and condoned and rewarded by wider

1459.text:
society. Surely this is the critical point
when it comes to climate change; that our

1464.text:
attitudes to climate change and climate risk
are mediated through the lens of our cultural

1469.text:
values and indeed the stories that we tell
around them. Clearly there is nothing impossible

1476.text:
about this issue at all. The fact that many
people are deeply concerned, active, engaged,

1482.text:
as I imagine that many of you are, is surely
proof that there is nothing inherently impossible

1488.text:
about this issue. But that is not to say that
we, I’d say this for myself, I’m sure

1494.text:
that might go for many of you, find it easy
to engage with an issue of this kind. It is

1499.text:
nonetheless hard for us to deal with things,
which have this formulation and therefore

1504.text:
even those of us who fully accept climate
change and what the science is telling us,

1510.text:
still need to translate it into narratives,
that make it comprehensible or imaginable

1519.text:
or immediate or certain or affordable, all
of these things which might otherwise block

1524.text:
us. As you heard I worked for many years as
a campaigner for campaign organisations. That’s

1529.text:
what campaign organisations do, that is why
there is a tension between campaign organisations

1534.text:
for example and scientists. The role of an
organisation like Greenpeace is to take the

1538.text:
science and make it immediate, to make it
of concern and that means obstructing those

1544.text:
biases and making it here and now and possible
and affordable and maybe to some degree a

1551.text:
threat. But what is maybe curious about climate
change is that most people show a remarkable

1557.text:
capacity to do the exact opposite. Having
decided not to take action, they can then

1563.text:
construct climate change in a shape that deliberately
creates distance and puts it as far away as

1570.text:
it can in time and space. In other words knowing
that we have obstacles in certain ways, they

1576.text:
even constructed around those obstacles, so
it’s a remarkable consistent quality of

1583.text:
attitude studies that people’s concern is
directly proportional to distance about climate

1589.text:
change. So asked whether climate change will
affect them, the vast majority of people say

1594.text:
‘no’. But they seem strangely more willing
to think that it will affect their family,

1599.text:
there might be some wishful thinking here,
and yet more willing to think that it might

1606.text:
affect their community, as if somehow strangely
it won’t affect them, there is some bubble

1610.text:
over them and their house, but it will affect
the people around them and more likely they

1614.text:
think that it will affect their country and
when it comes to other countries or other

1618.text:
species and then ultimately people in the
future, the risk of climate change becomes

1624.text:
far greater still.
So you find this strange situation in British

1627.text:
opinion polls, that more people will answer
‘yes’ to the question ‘is climate change
